Ernest Hemingway

A sportsman, a world citizen, and an author

    Noteworthy events in Hemingway's life:

  • 1899 - Ernest Miller Hemingway is born in Oak Park, Illinois.
  • 1918 - Hemingway volunteers as an ambulance driver in Italy during World War I.
  • 1919 - While wounded, Hemingway begins a brief but serious romance with nurse Agnes von Kurowsky. She would inspire the famous relationship of A Farewell to Arms.
  • 1921 - Hemingway marries Elizabeth Hadley Richardson, the first of four wives. They promptly move to Paris.
  • 1923 - Three Stories and Ten Poems, Hemingway's first novel, is published. Soon after, Hemingway's first son John is born.
  • 1926 - Hemingway's first novel, The Sun Also Rises, releases to critical acclaim.
  • 1927 - Elizabeth Hadley and Hemingway divorce. Hemingway marries Pauline Pfeiffer only a month later and publishes his short story collection Men Without Women.
  • 1928 - Ernest's second son, Patrick, is born in Key West where Hemingway will complete most of his life's writing.
  • 1929 - A Farewell to Arms is published, making Hemingway financially independent.
  • 1931 - The third and last Hemingway son, Gregory is born.
  • 1937 - Hemingway works as a war correspondent during the Spanish Civil War. To Have and Have Not is published.
  • 1937 - Hemingway works as a war correspondent during the Spanish Civil War. To Have and Have Not is published.
  • 1940 - Pauline Pfeiffer and Hemingway divorce. Hemingway marries Martha Gellhorn less than three weeks later. His novelized account of the Spanish Civil War, For Whom the Bell Tolls is published.
  • 1945 - Hemingway and Martha Gellhorn divorce.
  • 1946 - Mary Welsh and Ernest Hemingway marry. is published.
  • 1952 - The Old Man and the Sea, Hemingway's most successful work, is published in Life magazine.
  • 1953 - Ernest Hemingway receives the Pulitzer Prize for The Old Man and the Sea.
  • 1940 - Hemingway is awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
  • 1940 - Struggling with depression and alcoholism, Ernest Hemingway commits suicide with a shotgun at his home in Ketchum, Idaho.

"Every man's life ends the same way. It is only the details of how he lived and how he died that distinguish one man from another." -Ernest Hemingway

For more information, be sure to check the Wikipedia page on Ernest Hemingway.
